#Text=And this is the huge advantage with this kind of a mission — a " sample return " mission .

column1: #Text=Most missions rather do things quite differently ... you have to build an instrument to make a measurement and that instrument design gets locked in several years before launch practically guaranteeing that it will be obsolete by the time you launch .
#Text=Here exactly the opposite is true .
#Text=Several of the instruments that are now being used to analyze the cometary dust did not exist when the mission was launched .
#Text=Further , some instruments ( e. g. , synchrotrons ) are the size of shopping malls — you do n't have a hope of flying these in space .
#Text=So we can and will study these samples for many years .
#Text=AND we have to preserve some of these dust particles for our grandchildren to analyze with their hyper-quark-gluon plasma microscopes ( or whatever ) !
#Text=When do you anticipate the project to start ?
#Text=We 're really frustrated with the delays that we 've been having .
#Text=Some of it has to do with learning how to deal with the aerogel collectors , which are rougher and more fractured than we expected .

#Text=The good news is that they are pretty clean — there is very little of the dust that you see on our training images — these were deliberately left out in the lab to collect dust so that we could give people experience with the worst case we could think of .
#Text=In learning how to do the scanning of the actual flight aerogel , we uncovered a couple of bugs in our scanning software — which forced us to go back and rescan .

#Text=Part of the other reason for the delay was that we had to learn how to handle the collector — it would cost $200M to replace it if something happened to it , so we had to develop procedures to deal with it , and add several new safety features to the Cosmic Dust Lab .
#Text=This all took time .
#Text=Finally , we 're distracted because we also have many responsibilities for the cometary analysis , which has a deadline of August 15 for finishing analysis .
#Text=The IS project has no such deadline , so at times we had to delay the IS ( interstellar , sorry ) in order to focus on the cometary work .
#Text=We are very grateful to everyone for their patience on this — I mean that very sincerely .
#Text=And rest assured that we 're just as frustrated !
#Text=I know there will be a " test " that participants will have to take before they can examine the " real thing " .
#Text=What will that test consist of ?
#Text=The test will look very similar to the training images that you can look at now . But. . there will of course be no annotation to tell you where the tracks are !
